s.text: And the evidence that this produces downward mobility is distressingly strong.
And, in fact, in children this is exactly the case--at young ages, certainly under age 6 in the United States, lower-income kids are less likely to be obese than higher-income kids.
Certainly the obese, particularly obese women, face severe disadvantages in both the job and marriage markets.

Still, if thinness really becomes the ideal in every affluent culture--the way plumpness is in poor societies--it's curious.
The first report I found to document the effect class has on obesity was a 1965 study of midtown Manhattan residents.
